content_clusters.topic: OTP and Multi-Factor Authentication Delivery Issues
content_clusters.consolidation_notes: Article 14303986197649 provides complete activation workflow. Navigation map entries confirm the Profile > Security Settings > MFA path.
Tickets covering MFA disable functionality, email notifications, and user-reported error messages during disable process. One support issue (TSSD-781) indicates UX friction.
Large cluster of Finance module integration tickets covering MFA flows for corporate cards, expenses, card creation/editing, and role elevation. All completed except FIN-1802 (Backlog).
Tickets for UI and copy refinements in MFA setup/disable flows and role elevation. Multiple tickets marked 'Won't Do', indicating deprioritized UX improvements.
MFA handling in claims app and authentication code input errors. One support ticket (TSSD-740) cancelled, suggesting issue may have been resolved or deprioritized.

content_clusters.topic: MFA Disable/Recovery Restrictions for Finance Roles
content_clusters.consolidation_notes: Tickets describe intentional security restrictions on MFA disablement for payment-critical roles and UX inconsistencies in the disable flow. Root cause: by-design security constraint with incomplete UX standardization.

content_clusters.topic: Access Control and Permission Configuration Gaps
content_clusters.consolidation_notes: Both tickets describe insufficient granular permission and access level configuration capabilities across modules (Attendance, general platform). Root cause: feature gap in role-based access control.

content_clusters.topic: Authentication Flow and Session Management UX Issues
content_clusters.consolidation_notes: Tickets describe missing or inconsistent authentication confirmation and logout dialog mechanisms. Root cause: incomplete UX coverage in authentication workflows.

content_clusters.topic: OAuth Token and Attachment Download Issues
content_clusters.consolidation_notes: Single ticket describing OAuth token handling inconsistencies in development environments affecting attachment downloads. Root cause: token management issue in authentication layer.
Single ticket describing security exploit in Excel import/export actions. Root cause: application-level security vulnerability in file handling.

detected_integrations.description: External third-party app used to generate time-based authentication codes (TOTP). Required for MFA activation, login, and deactivation workflows. User must download and install on iOS or Android device.
Core Bayzat system that stores MFA configuration state and provides the UI for enabling/disabling MFA. Manages the relationship between user accounts and their MFA status.
MFA is integrated into Finance module for payment security, protecting card creation, editing, unfreezing, expense overview, and balance operations.
MFA/2FA verification is implemented in claims app to secure claim-related operations.
Email notifications are sent to users when MFA is disabled, providing audit trail and security awareness.
MFA is used to gate role elevation and sensitive permission changes, requiring MFA verification before privilege escalation.

MFA integration with payment endpoints, card transactions, and payment authorization flows. Requires MFA protection for payment-critical actions and conditional MFA requirements based on company configuration.
Access control and permission configuration gaps affecting Attendance module's ability to enforce granular permission settings.
OTP and authentication flow integration for transaction processors. Lacks OTP resend mechanism and post-authentication confirmation interface.
Bearer token handling in authentication layer, particularly in development environments where multiple tokens cause exceptions.
Security vulnerability in bulk data transfer operations affecting file handling and data integrity.

steps: Go to Profile by clicking the profile avatar (top-right)
Click Enable next to Multi-factor Authentication
Download Google Authenticator app (iOS or Android)
Scan the QR code displayed in the security settings
Enter the authentication code from Google Authenticator
Verify the code to complete activation
what_to_do.expected_outcome: Multi-factor Authentication is successfully enabled on the user account. A timed code (refreshing every 30 seconds) from Google Authenticator will be required for all future logins.
rules_and_constraints: Requires a mobile device with iOS or Android operating system
Google Authenticator app must be downloaded and installed before scanning the QR code
Authentication code is time-based and changes every 30 seconds
User must have access to the mobile device during activation to scan QR code and verify
edge_cases: User does not have a compatible mobile device (iOS or Android) — cannot proceed with MFA activation
User fails to scan QR code correctly — must retry or request a new QR code
User enters incorrect authentication code — must wait for code to refresh and retry

steps: Enter your login credentials (username/email and password)
Open the Google Authenticator app on your mobile device
Retrieve the current authentication code (6-digit code that refreshes every 30 seconds)
Enter the authentication code in the MFA prompt
what_to_do.expected_outcome: User successfully authenticates with both standard credentials and the time-based code from Google Authenticator. Access to the Bayzat platform is granted.
rules_and_constraints: Multi-factor Authentication must be pre-activated on the user account before this workflow can be used
Authentication code is valid for 30 seconds — user must enter it within this window
Google Authenticator app must be accessible on the user's mobile device at login time
edge_cases: User enters an expired authentication code (older than 30 seconds) — login fails and user must retry with a fresh code
User does not have access to their mobile device at login time — cannot complete MFA step
User enters an incorrect code — login fails and user must retry

steps: Go to Profile by clicking the profile avatar (top-right)
Click Disable next to Multi-factor Authentication
Enter the verification code from your Google Authenticator app
what_to_do.expected_outcome: Multi-factor Authentication is successfully disabled on the user account. Future logins will only require standard credentials (username/email and password) without the additional MFA code step.
rules_and_constraints: User must have access to Google Authenticator app to retrieve the verification code required for deactivation
Deactivation requires verification to prevent unauthorized removal of the security layer
edge_cases: User does not have access to Google Authenticator app — cannot complete deactivation without the verification code
User enters an incorrect verification code — deactivation fails and user must retry with a fresh code

what_to_watch_out_for.limitation: Users encounter unclear or confusing error messages when attempting to disable MFA. The disable flow requires MFA code verification, but error messaging may not adequately guide users through the process or explain why the operation failed.

MFA integration across Finance/Cards module spans multiple endpoints and workflows (card creation, editing, unfreezing, expense overview, balances, role elevation). While implementation is complete, the distributed nature of MFA enforcement across many financial operations creates potential for inconsistent user experience or missed coverage areas.
what_to_watch_out_for.design_rationale: MFA is intentionally applied to sensitive financial operations for security. Multiple endpoints require MFA to protect payment and card management actions.

what_to_watch_out_for.limitation: Multiple UI and copy improvements for MFA setup/disable flows and role elevation screens have been marked 'Won't Do'. Users may encounter inconsistent messaging, unclear instructions, or suboptimal UX in MFA-gated workflows across different features.

Users report errors when entering authentication codes during MFA verification. The exact error conditions and user-facing messaging are unclear, but the issue affects the core MFA verification flow in claims app and potentially other modules.

what_to_watch_out_for.theme: Incomplete MFA Coverage in Payment Endpoints and Cards Module
what_to_watch_out_for.limitation: The MFA integration with the Finance/Cards module has historically had incomplete endpoint coverage and inconsistent MFA marker application. Users performing payment-critical actions may encounter endpoints that lack proper MFA protection or have missing MFA initialization logic, creating security gaps in payment workflows.

what_to_watch_out_for.theme: MFA Disablement Restrictions for Finance-Critical Roles
what_to_watch_out_for.limitation: Users with finance-critical roles (e.g., Accounts Payable) cannot disable MFA through standard admin interfaces due to intentional security restrictions. When users lose access to their authenticator device, they cannot self-service recover their account and must request manual backend intervention. Additionally, the MFA disable popup interface lacks standardization and centralization across the platform.
what_to_watch_out_for.design_rationale: Security constraint to protect payment-critical operations from unauthorized MFA disablement
what_to_watch_out_for.documented_workaround: Contact backend support for manual MFA reset for finance-critical roles

what_to_watch_out_for.theme: Insufficient Granular Permission and Access Control Configuration
what_to_watch_out_for.limitation: The Bayzat platform lacks comprehensive granular permission configuration capabilities across modules. Users cannot define custom roles with fine-grained access controls, set module-specific permission levels, or configure low-precision permission prompts. This limitation affects modules like Attendance and general platform access management, preventing HR Admins from implementing nuanced access control strategies.

what_to_watch_out_for.theme: Inconsistent Authentication Confirmation and Logout Dialog UX
what_to_watch_out_for.limitation: The platform lacks consistent post-authentication confirmation interfaces and logout dialog mechanisms. Registered users with active invitations may not see expected logout dialogs, and the post-login success confirmation is not standardized across authentication flows. This creates unpredictable user experience in session management workflows.

what_to_watch_out_for.theme: Missing OTP Resend Mechanism in Benefits Authentication
what_to_watch_out_for.limitation: The Bayzat Benefits authentication process lacks a built-in OTP resend capability. Transaction processors who do not receive their OTP cannot request a new code, forcing them to wait or contact support. This creates friction in the login recovery workflow and reduces self-service capability.

what_to_watch_out_for.theme: OAuth Token Handling Inconsistencies in Development Environments
what_to_watch_out_for.limitation: The platform experiences OAuth token handling issues in development environments where multiple bearer tokens in request headers cause authentication exceptions. This prevents reliable attachment downloads during testing and validation phases, affecting QA workflows and document retrieval functionality.

what_to_watch_out_for.theme: Security Vulnerability in Excel Import/Export Actions
what_to_watch_out_for.limitation: The platform contains a security exploit in Excel import/export actions that exposes potential risks in data transfer and file handling processes. This vulnerability requires core application-level remediation and affects data integrity in bulk operations.
